required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Safety and Tolerability Study of 10XB-101 Injections in Adult Subjects With Extra Fat Under the Chin ("Double Chin")
clinical_study.official_title: A Multi-Center, Open Label, Single Ascending Dose Safety and Tolerability Study of Subcutaneously Administered 10XB-101 in Adult Subjects With Excessive Submental Fat

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to find out more about an investigational drug, 10XB-101, for people with fat under their chin which they would like to remove. The Sponsor of this study thinks there may be a chance this drug could be used to dissolve, or "melt" this fat away.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Multi-center, open label, single ascending dose comparison.

primary_outcome.description: Incidence (severity and causality) of any local and systemic Adverse Events

At each time point, the number of subjects with presence (and severity) of the following LSRs on a 4 point scale (zero to 3), with a higher score indicating a worse outcome: erythema, edema, tenderness on palpation, bruising, pain, and stinging/burning

secondary_outcome.description: Change from Baseline in the CSFS on a five-point scale (zero to 4), with a higher score indicating a worse outcome
Change from Baseline in the PSFS on a five-point scale (zero to 4), with a higher score indicating a worse outcome

arm_group.description: Participants receive 10XB-101 Solution for Injection, 1.25% or 2.0% via subcutaneous injection up to 10 mL on Day 1 of subject participation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subject is a male or non-pregnant female 18-65 years of age
- Signed informed consent
- Subject has a score of 2 or 3 on the Clinician Submental Fat Scale (CSFS) at Visit 2/Baseline
- Subject is in good general health
Exclusion Criteria:
- Loose skin or prominent platysmal bands in the neck or chin area
- Recent treatment with anticoagulants
- Presence of clinically significant health problems
